verses.text: When they entered Ecbatana, Tobias said, 'Brother Azariah, lead me straight to the house of Raguel.' So he brought him to Raguel's house, and they found him sitting at the door of the courtyard. They greeted him first, and he replied, 'Greetings to you, brothers. Welcome!' He invited them into his house.
verses.comment: The emphasis on hospitality here echoes Abraham’s encounter in Genesis 18, and later Christian teaching on welcoming strangers. Raguel’s opening of his home recalls the call to charity and openness to God's messengers.

verses.text: Raguel said to Edna his wife, 'How much this young man resembles my cousin Tobit!'
verses.comment: Family resemblances are important in ancient cultures for recognition and kinship. Note that Edna is named, which highlights the role of women in the household.

verses.text: Raguel asked them, 'Where do you come from, brothers?' They replied, 'We are sons of Naphtali, taken captive in Nineveh.'
verses.comment: Their identity as exiles from Naphtali roots their story in Israel’s history under Assyrian captivity, connecting the personal narrative to larger salvation history.

verses.text: Raguel said, 'So you know Tobit, our kinsman?' They answered, 'Yes, we know him.'
verses.comment: Recognition among the dispersed Israelites links the faithfulness of God’s covenant people, even outside the Promised Land.

verses.text: Raguel said, 'He is my cousin. What is his health? Is he well?' They replied, 'He is alive and well.' Then Tobias added, 'He is my father.'
verses.comment: This direct link reveals the nearness of the family. In biblical tradition, the well-being of one’s relatives is cherished (see 3 John 1:2).

verses.text: Raguel jumped up and embraced Tobias and wept. He said, 'Blessings on you, my child, son of a good and noble father!' When he heard that Tobit had lost his sight, he was grieved and wept.
verses.comment: Physical gestures—embrace, tears—show the strength of family bonds. Note the blessing given over Tobias, reflecting a tradition of imparting spiritual well-being through spoken blessing.

verses.text: He also spoke to him as follows, “Blessings on you, my child, son of a good and noble father! O most miserable of calamities that such an upright and beneficent man has become blind!” He then embraced his kinsman Tobias and wept.
verses.comment: Notice the shared sorrow and joyful welcome by the women of the house. This mirrors New Testament depictions of love and compassion in the community of believers (see John 11:35).

verses.text: His wife Edna also wept for him, and their daughter Sarah likewise wept.
verses.comment: The shared weeping of Edna and Sarah emphasizes both the depth of familial grief and the anxiety surrounding Sarah’s repeated tragedies (see Tobit 3:7-9), highlighting the emotional context that frames the marriage proposal.
verses.sectionHeader: Tobias Seeks Sarah’s Hand in Marriage

verses.text: Then Raguel slaughtered a ram from the flock and received them very warmly. When they had bathed and washed themselves and had reclined to dine, Tobias said to Raphael, “Brother Azariah, ask Raguel to give me my kinswoman Sarah.”
verses.comment: Marriage within the broader family ensured the preservation of inheritance and faith. The faithfulness of Tobias in seeking this arrangement underlines both obedience and the sanctity of marriage as a divine ordinance.

verses.text: But Raguel overheard it and said to the lad, “Eat and drink, and be merry tonight. For no one except you, brother, has the right to marry my daughter Sarah. Likewise I am not at liberty to give her to any other man than yourself, because you are my nearest relative. But let me explain to you the true situation more fully, my child.
verses.comment: Raguel’s honesty and sorrow point to the mysterious suffering of Sarah. The motif of seven unsuccessful suitors recalls God’s sovereignty even amid repeated tragedy.

verses.text: I have given her to seven men of our kinsmen, and all died on the night when they went in to her. But now, my child, eat and drink, and the Lord will act on behalf of you both.” But Tobias said, “I will neither eat nor drink anything until you settle the things that pertain to me.” So Raguel said, “I will do so. She is given to you in accordance with the decree in the book of Moses, and it has been decreed from heaven that she be given to you. Take your kinswoman; from now on you are her brother and she is your sister. She is given to you from today and forever. May the Lord of heaven, my child, guide and prosper you both this night and grant you mercy and peace.”
verses.comment: Tobias’ confidence in divine providence and destiny shows trust in God’s sovereign plan (cf. Ephesians 1:11). The idea of marriage being divinely appointed from the beginning resonates with the Christian view of God’s hand in matrimony.

verses.text: Then Raguel summoned his daughter Sarah. When she came to him, he took her by the hand and gave her to Tobias, saying, 'Take her to be your wife in accordance with the law and decree written in the book of Moses. Take her and bring her safely to your father. And may the God of heaven prosper your journey with his peace.'
verses.comment: Raguel’s reference to the Book of Moses and 'Heaven decrees' highlights marriage as a sacred covenant in accordance with divine law. This line also subtly affirms the authority of written Scripture and tradition in matters of faith.

verses.text: Then he called her mother and told her to bring writing material; and he wrote out a copy of a marriage contract, to the effect that he gave her to him as wife according to the decree of the law of Moses.
verses.comment: The writing of a marriage contract reflects Jewish legal practices of the time (cf. Exodus 24:7; Malachi 2:14), demonstrating care to ensure the union follows the Law of Moses—underscoring the theme of faithfulness to God’s covenant.
verses.sectionHeader: The Marriage of Tobias and Sarah

verses.text: Then they began to eat and drink.
verses.comment: The act of eating and drinking together signifies the joyful celebration and social ratification of the marriage alliance, a standard practice in ancient Jewish weddings (cf. Genesis 29:22).

verses.text: Raguel called his wife Edna and said to her, "Sister, get the other room ready, and take her there."
verses.comment: Raguel’s instruction to Edna to prepare a separate room displays the custom of bridal chambers in Jewish weddings (cf. Judges 15:1), emphasizing the solemnity and propriety of the marital union.

verses.text: So she went and made the bed in the room as he had told her, and brought Sarah there. She wept for her daughter. Then, wiping away the tears, she said to her, “Take courage, my daughter; the Lord of heaven grant you joy in place of your sorrow. Take courage, my daughter.” Then she went out.
verses.comment: Edna’s maternal compassion and blessing—encouraging Sarah to trust in God—mirrors themes of suffering, hope, and divine intervention seen throughout Tobit (cf. Tobit 3:16-17), highlighting faith in God’s ability to transform sorrow into joy.
verses.sectionHeader: Sarah Prepared for Her Wedding Night

verses.text: So she went and made the room ready, just as Raguel told her. She brought Sarah there, and she wept for her daughter. Then Edna wiped away her tears and said, 'Take courage, my child. May the Lord of heaven exchange your sorrow for joy. Take courage, my daughter.'
verses.comment: Edna’s motherly comfort points to themes of hope and restoration emphasized throughout the Bible, culminating in the promise that God turns mourning into joy (see Isaiah 61:3, John 16:20).
